frameDefinitions: These words relate to the relative ordering of two events or times.
An Experiencer has an easy or difficult time carrying out an Activity.
An Agent pauses in the course of an Activity. '' 'The government froze settlement construction in 1992 to facilitate peace talks.'
A Cause (or associated Actor) causes an ongoing Process to temporarily stop.
In this frame, an Agent or Cause changes the timing of an Event.

In this frame a Hindrance makes it more difficult for a Protagonist to complete their intended Action or a Hindrance directly affects an Action where the Action can be a natural act or the actions of many individuals in a collective endeavor.
frameExamples: <t>After</t> she arrived , she laid out her papers on the desk.
The government <t>froze</t> settlement construction in 1992 to facilitate peace talks.
Malcolm was <t>hindered</t> by his drinking problem .
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Focal_occasion</fen> is the event which is  being located in time with respect to some other event: The <fen>Focal_occasion</fen> is profiled, in contrast to the <fen>Landmark_occasion</fen>, which is backgrounded.
The <fen>Landmark_occasion</fen> is the event  with respect to which the <fen>Focal_occasion</fen> is located.
The <fen>Focal_participant</fen> is the participant in the <fen>Focal_occasion</fen> which is profiled as being in a relation of relative time to the <fen>Landmark_occasion</fen>.

This Frame Element marks expressions indicating the <fen>Activity</fen> that the <fen>Experiencer</fen> finds difficult or easy. In many cases, the relevant <fen>Activity</fen> has to be inferred from the context.
This Frame Element marks expressions that indicate which person judges carrying out the <fen>Activity</fen> to be easy or difficult.
The time at which the <fen>Activity</fen> takes place.
This role identifies the <fen>Activity</fen> for which an <fen>Agent</fen> is pausing.
An <fen>Agent</fen> pauses in the course of an <fen>Activity</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> at which an <fen>Agent</fen> pauses in the course of an <fen>Activity</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where an <fen>Agent</fen> pauses in the course of an <fen>Activity</fen>.
A force, process, or event that produces the interruption.
The <fen>Process</fen> goes into a paused state due to the <fen>Cause</fen> or <fen>Actor</fen>.
An entity which participates in a <fen>Cause</fen>, perhaps volitionally and perhaps not, but effectively causing the interruption.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the interruption occurs.
Where the interruption takes place.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the animate entity which brings about the change in time of the <fen>Event</fen>.
The <fen>Cause</fen> is the non-sentient force which brings about the change of time for the <fen>Event</fen>.
The <fen>Event</fen> is the occurrence which changes time.
The time at which the delay occurred.
The location at which the expected time of the <fen>Event</fen> changes.
The <fen>Protagonist</fen> is the entity that tends towards or plans some <fen>Action</fen> which the <fen>Hindrance</fen> causes to be more difficult.
The <fen>Hindrance</fen> is the force which makes the <fen>Action</fen> more difficult or less likely to be successfully completed. The <fen>Hindrance</fen> may be a lack of enabling force:

The <fen>Action</fen> is what the <fen>Protagonist</fen> desires to do, which is made more difficult by the <fen>Hindrance</fen>. It can also be a natural act or collective endeavor, not linked to an overt <fen>Protagonist</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the <fen>Hindrance</fen> affects the <fen>Protagonist</fen> or <fen>Action</fen>.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the location where  he <fen>Hindrance</fen> affects the <fen>Protagonist</fen> or <fen>Action</fen>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Hours of eating and drinking</fex> followed the wedding ceremony.
Hours of eating and drinking followed <fex>the wedding ceremony</fex>.
The geology question on the exam was hard <fex>for me</fex>.
<fex>Leaving the page after you've clicked 'Download'</fex> will interrupt the transfer.
Leaving the page after you've clicked 'Download' will interrupt <fex>the transfer</fex>.
In such cases <fex>the server</fex> will automatically interrupt the process.
<fex>The opening of the musical</fex> was delayed.
The project was hampered <fex>by a lack of funds</fex>.
